On this segment we look under the hood—options probabilities, volatility, trading strategies, futures, you name it—so your trading mechanics are built to manage more winners.

item.title: Core Differences: Stocks & ETFs
item.description: On average, ETFs carry lower IVs than individual stocks, and therefore ETFs tend to be less risky to trade. This is due to most ETFs being heavily diversified by default. However, when placing a trade, the implied volatility is the final determinant of the asset’s risk: an ETF and stock that have the same IV both carry identical risk profiles at that point in time. Therefore, whether an underlying is a stock or ETF is irrelevant. The IV of the underlying is what determines the risk.

item.title: S&P Pullbacks
item.description:
We are currently on a 200 calendar day bull run without having seen a 5% pullback within 1 month from peak to trough. How unusual is this?

Well, from 1993 - 2021, there have only been 14 other occasions where we saw a 200+ calendar day bull run without a 5% pullback.

Some believe the frequent new all-time highs mean the market is overextended. So if we see a pullback of 5%, can history provide insight into what comes next?

The market has been on an incredible bull run, but what happens if we see a pullback?

item.title: What Is a Standard Deviation?
item.description: Standard deviations give us context around the typical fluctuations around daily returns or trade P/Ls that happen around 70% of the time. Comparing standard deviations of different option strategy P/Ls or underlying returns allows for a fair comparison of their risks. Higher standard deviations mean higher risk. Be aware that outlier risk is not accounted for in standard deviation, and the only way to protect yourself from these is to stay small.

item.title: What If We Hold to Expiration?
item.description: From first glance, “average P/L” and “volatility of P/L” tell us that holding until expiration is definitively a bad deal; but we know from liquid and efficient markets, there is no “bad” or “good” deal: just two sides of a fair trade. While managing at 21 DTE is simple and provides the most “well-balanced” risk and return for most investors, holding to expiration may be considered to maximize the trade’s POP (especially if a trade is at a mild loss at 21 DTE).

item.title: Volatility During All Time Highs
item.description: Since 1990, the market went to all time highs around 8% of the time. However, this 8% is not independent on a daily basis. If the market has corrected 10%, the chance that tomorrow will be an all time high is obviously near-zero. Since volatility values shrink when markets rise, we saw a typical VIX value to be nearly 25% lower when the market makes an all time high compared to a random day.

item.title: POP-Weighted Portfolios
item.description: The Kelly Criterion can be used to estimate the percentage of portfolio capital that should be allocated to a position to maximize long-term growth rate. Today, let’s use the Kelly formalism (combined with the portfolio allocation guidelines) to construct a sample POP-weighted portfolio and see how that affects risk. Join Tom, Tony and Julia as they discuss POP-weighted portfolios.

item.title: The Fallibility of Statistical Studies
item.description:
Historical backtests of strategies tell you solely what happened over that specific time period, and they should not be used to conclude the strategy’s future viability. The degree of the “statistical significance” of a claim depends on mainly two things:
  1. How likely is it that results are influenced by random noise compared to a known reason (correlation vs causation)?
  2. Would accepting the claim contradict previously proven claims?
In this case, is GOOGL’s risk/reward pricing wrong, or was the GOOGL study just affected by a lot of variance over that timeframe? Both cannot be true.

item.title: lookback vs Research
item.description:
lookback uses a slightly different backtesting method than most of our in-house research, and therefore the results of a study will be different between the two methods. Even though the results will vary, both methods of backtesting will generally lead to the same interpretation of the strategy... a few dollars difference in average P/Ls over 15 years should not change your perception of the validity of the strategy. 

Risk defined strategies will have less of a difference since they are, by nature, less volatile strategies. Undefined risk strategies will have a bigger divergence.

item.title: Interpreting lookback Results
item.description: lookback may revolutionize the way that retail investors are able to gather and analyze historical financial data since it offers an extremely user friendly way to backtest any options strategies on any underlying. However, as with any new software, take all results with a grain of salt since lookback conducts the backtest in a very specific way that may not be representative of all portfolios that trade the same strategy.

item.title: Crypto Correlations Over Time
item.description: Since correlation between large crypto has been high and stable since 2018, there is potential for hedging and pairs trades especially when futures and options become liquid. The current three-month correlation between Bitcoin and the S&P 500 is a weak 0.14, implying virtually no relationship between equities and crypto. This correlation has historically fluctuated between -0.50 and +0.50 (never strong) meaning crypto may become a key asset to use when diversifying equity positions.

item.title: Comparing Strategy Risk
item.description: When underlyings are liquid, IVs can be used to compare the purest expectations of risk between them without having to adjust for the prices of the underlyings. By using both IV and underlying price, we are able to determine how many units of a strategy in one underlying will equal the risk of one unit of the same strategy in another. For the most comparable results, the strategy in both underlyings should keep the deltas used for each strikes constant, the expiration cycle the same, and liquidity high .

item.title: Correlation May Not Tell All
item.description: In some cases, the correlation value between two stocks may not mean what people think intuitively: think of SPY vs. IWM compared to SPY and SMH. Beta helps solve this problem by taking into account not just the price direction relationship, but also the volatility relationship between the two. Usually (like on tastyworks), beta is calculated in terms of an index, meaning that the beta of an asset is in terms of correlation to and volatility of SPY.

item.title: Comparing Last Year's Rally
item.description: Comparing this period’s performance using long stock vs. a short 50∆ put, we can see that depending on the IV change of the underlying, the short puts may have performed better or worse over that period compared to long stock, but the risk-reward held in proportion. Even in the most turbulent periods in stock market history, short puts (which are commonly misunderstood as speculative and “more risky than long stock”) actually carried a risk-reward that was very similar to their outright underlyings, with some variability due to implied volatility fluctuations.

item.title: Decay and Early Management
item.description: Our decision to manage trades at 21 days to expiration is derived from extensive research that holds with theoretical expectations and actual historical performance of OTM options. Because 75% of the profit of a SPY 16∆ strangle was realized by the trade’s halfway point, on average, re-deploying capital in new positions has shown to generate more profits over time (since you'd be receiving 75% of potential P/L in 50% of the trade time).

item.title: Russell's Divergence
item.description:
tastytrade reviews the divergence in the price and volatility relationship between SPY and IWM.

Key Takeaways:

The correlation between SPY and IWM has been sustained at low levels for a record 164 trading days and counting. 

Since 2020, IWM has carried a higher than average volatility differential to SPY...around 9 points higher IV than SPY. The lower correlation lends itself to higher diversification even between strategies in equity indexes. 

The current correlation may provide additional reductions in portfolio volatility when trading both SPY and IWM compared to trading only one or the other.

item.title: Small Moves and Reversals
item.description: Since 1990, the probability of a day with an intraday reversal in the SPX has been around 16%. The probability of a reversal after a selloff is slightly greater than the probability of a reversal after a rally. The probability of seeing a large magnitude reversal is the same for rallies as it is for selloffs. The Market Measures from Monday covered the probability of seeing a reversal given the current performance of the day.

item.title: The Odds of an Intraday Reversal
item.description: Given the market is up or down at least 0.5% today, there is around a 1 in 5 chance that the market closes the opposite direction that it opened. The chance of such reversal increases with IV, with higher magnitude reversals being almost exclusively high IV phenomena. Although reversals after rallies tend to be slightly less common than equal reversals after selloffs, the difference is marginal.

item.title: Various Crypto Volatilities
item.description: Over the last three years, it seems that the historical volatility of mainstream crypto has been mean reverting (to an extent) and is currently sitting around 10% below its average. Because of the lack of a tradable and liquid options market and the ability to efficiently go long and short crypto, the market is not in a fully matured state. As a result, historic volatility values may not be representative of future expectations.
